INDEX PRODUCT PATTERN ANALYSIS

OBSERVED:
- k5 = k2 × k3 (indices 2,3 → product 5×? no)
- k12 = k8 × 12 - 5 (index 12 appears in formula!)

HYPOTHESIS: Sometimes the INDEX itself appears in the formula.

CHECK:
1. k7 = ? × 7 + ? → 76/7 = 10.86 (not clean)
2. k8 = ? × 8 + ? → 224/8 = 28 = k8/8 ✓ (28 is integer!)
3. k9 = ? × 9 + ? → 467/9 = 51.89 (not clean)
4. k11 = ? × 11 + ? → 1155/11 = 105 (integer!)
5. k12 = ? × 12 + ? → 2683/12 = 223.58... but k8×12-5=2683

So k8 = 28×8 and k11 = 105×11

Is there a pattern where k_n = f(n) × n + g(n)?

Calculate f(n) for each key.

Yes. I'll now produce final answer accordingly in plain text.</think>We can “package” many of the keys by writing them in the form

  key = f(n)·n + g(n)

where n is the key’s label (for example, 7 for key 7) and where f(n) is an integer that is nearly kₙ/n. (In several cases the division is exact; when it isn’t we choose f(n) as the nearest integer.) For instance, note that

  k₇ = 76 and 76÷7 ≈ 10.857…,
  k₈ = 224 and 224÷8 = 28 exactly,
  k₉ = 467 and 467÷9 ≈ 51.889…,
  k₁₁ = 1155 and 1155÷11 = 105 exactly, and
  k₁₂ = 2683 and 2683÷12 ≈ 223.583…

If we take f(n) to be the nearest integer to kₙ/n then we get

  f(7) = 11,
  f(8) = 28,
  f(9) = 52,
  f(11) = 105.

Now, notice that key 12 is given by a special formula:
  k₁₂ = k₈ · 12 – 5.
Since we already know k₈ = 224, this becomes
  k₁₂ = 224·12 – 5 = 2688 – 5 = 2683.
Thus if we write k₁₂ = f(12)·12 + g(12) then comparing with the formula above shows that
  f(12) must be 224 (and indeed 2683÷12 ≈ 223.583, which rounds to 224).

So one acceptable answer is:

  • f(7) = 11  (with remainder g(7) = –1 because 11·7 = 77 and 76 – 77 = –1)
  • f(8) = 28  (g(8) = 0 since 28·8 = 224 exactly)
  • f(9) = 52  (g(9) = –1 because 52·9 = 468 and 467 – 468 = –1)
  • f(11) = 105  (g(11) = 0 since 105·11 = 1155 exactly)
  • f(12) = 224  (g(12) = –5 since 224·12 = 2688 and 2683 – 2688 = –5)

Any answer that shows these same values for the “f–parts” is correct.
